abstract: Hollywood's box-office blues continued over the weekend.
snippet: Hollywood's box-office blues continued over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood's box-office blues continued over the weekend as remakes of "Footloose" and "The Thing" fizzled. "Real Steel" (DreamWorks Studios) repeated as No. 1 by a sliver, taking in about $16.3 million for a two-week total of $51.7 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing statistics. "Footloose" stumbled in second place, selling an estimated $16.1 million in tickets, a frail result given the months-long marketing push that Paramount Pictures lavished on the film. The good news: "Footloose," built around a cast of unknowns, cost only about $24 million to make. "The Thing" (Universal Pictures) was third with $8.7 million in ticket sales - not exactly a bloodbath given its production cost of about $38 million but a disappointment nonetheless. George Clooney's "Ides of March" (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was fourth, taking in about $7.5 million for a two-week total of $22.2 million. "Dolphin Tale" (Warner Brothers) rounded out the top five with $6.3 million in ticket sales, lifting its four-week tally to $58.7 million. For the weekend, North American theaters recorded $89 million in ticket sales, a 32 percent drop from the same weekend last year.
